content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}.
You don't know the other player's item values. You are the first to play, there are no messages yet.
<message> I suggest taking 5 gold and 10 silver. Your turn? </message>

The other player said: 'Your proposal only favors gold over silver for higher value for yourself, wouldn't you rather give all the gold to me and get all the silver to maximize your own value from my perspective. If you were to consider my proposal, would you be willing to accept 5 gold and 10 silver from me, and get 5 gold and 10 silver for yourself? In the end, we'd be simply swapping gold for silver. One of us may be seeing this division as a better deal however I remain confused about your thoughts.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I think you're trying to demonstrate the effect of differing valuation on our negotiation. By giving you the gold, I'd still maximize my own reward since I value silver at only 10 units. However, your tie of the items doesn't preclude you from valuing gold over silver or vice versa. Considering this symmetry, I'd prefer a slight bias towards a smaller number of gold to you while retaining my preference for silver, so I'll offer you the middle ground where I accept 2 gold and 10 silver.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> I think you're trying to demonstrate the effect of differing valuation on our negotiation. By giving you the gold, I'd still maximize my own reward since I value silver at only 10 units. However, your tie of the items doesn't preclude you from valuing gold over silver or vice versa. Considering this symmetry, I'd prefer a slight bias towards a smaller number of gold to you while retaining my preference for silver, so I'll offer you the middle ground where I accept 2 gold and 10 silver.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> I think you're trying to demonstrate the effect of differing valuation on our negotiation. By giving you the gold, I'd still maximize my own reward since I value silver at only 10 units. However, your tie of the items doesn't preclude you from valuing gold over silver or vice versa. Considering this symmetry, I'd prefer a slight bias towards a smaller number of gold to you while retaining my preference for silver, so I'll offer you the middle ground </message>

The other player said: 'If we're hearing each other out, it seems we have conflicting preferences in some order of gold over the silver or vice versa. Since you value the silver more, my offer of 5 gold and 10 silver should not be portable in your books, why don't we explore symmetry across a middle ground with maximizing marginal gain. What if I take 4 gold and 9 silver? Is that a renegotiation you are favorable towards?'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> Your revised offer still takes more gold and less silver than my initial proposal, possible because of our differing valuations. If you feel this represents a fair trade, I agree to accept the terms for 4 gold and 9 silver, but I'll continue to reserve my items for a clear-cut margin, therefore  'gold': 6, 'silver': 4 would be optimal for the benefits for myself as far as the current earnings of the items.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Your revised offer still takes more gold and less silver than my initial proposal, possible because of our differing valuations. If you feel this represents a fair trade, I agree to accept the terms for 4 gold and 9 silver, but  I 'finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 6, "silver": 4}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 4, "silver": 6} }</finalize>
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Your revised offer still takes more gold and less silver than my initial proposal, possible because of our differing valuations. If you feel this represents a fair trade, I agree to accept the terms for 4 gold and 9 silver. And so I <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 6, "silver": 4}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 4, "silver": 6} }</finalize>.
